data.text: Trek Domane AL3 Disc vs Marin Gestalt 1 for Long Distance Touring

Hello friends I am looking to buy the best long touring road bike and I have chosen 2 bicycles, The 1st one is Trek Domane AL3 Disc and the 2nd one is Marin Gestalt 1. So kindly suggest to me which will be better from these 2 models and why. Thank you
Both of these Look like Road (racing) bikes to me. Touring bikes typically have wider tires and rack mounts and pannier racks to carry your stuff (tent, clothes,sleeping bag etc) for multiday tours
data.author: Eric Linfoot

data.text: From looking at them I would say the Marin as more relaxed geometry.
data.author: Michael McCutcheon

data.text: The Trek Domane is an established master in the endurance cycling world. it is designed to soak up the bumps and provide long distance comfort. I often ride my SL7 for 8 to 12 hours. The AL3 is near the bottom of the Domane range so all the comfort feature have not trickeled down, but its very solid. I has a second hand AL3 for my TACX indoor trainer, whils i ride my SL7 outdoors. The TACX has a vibration featur to simulate cobble stones, gravell etc. You hardly feel it on the AL3, but I sure do in my Hardtail MTB!. You may also wan to note that the Trek Pro team and TreK Segafredo now use the Perelli P-ZERO Race TLR tires and have droped the standard Botranger tires. Again i can testify to how comfortable they are. A new Domane AL3 with take 35C tires. i use the P-Zero 30x700 and wow they are good. Although the are cales RACE, perelli claim they are an endurance tire and again I can testify to that. Just note the max wight (combined rider, bike, and baggage ) rating for the AL3 is 125Kg or 275lbs. I don't know the marlin, and htey dont state a max weight, so I cant compare however it does appear to have more spokes per wheel which may or may not be a good sign)

data.text: The Geometry of the Trek Domane never been designed for Long Distance cycling. Being said, i did try 500 KM within 3 days with My Trek Madone but i it not recommended. Trek has a link of product called "Check Point" which made for Gravel/Long distance. For long distance you need to looking for more up and straight frame , good Tire Clearance and options to attach things on your frame (Like on Forks, Top tube and etc).You always can change the a component like handelbar, but not your Frame!. Make sure to have a right bike fit before buying it the bike. Always remember the best bike is the best fit bike!!.
data.author: Keyvan Shariat

data.text: The key words are "touring bikes" or "gravel bikes", Google them. Criteria will be: - gearing ratio If you are on a light setup (bikepacking, a gravel bike will do like front 30-46 and back 11-36) giving gearing ratio of at least (or better say at most) 30/36=83%, If on a heav setup with panniers (bike touring), you will have triple crankset in front with lowest gearing ratio of around 65% (22/34, or 24/36 or something like that) - tire clearance (I like to have around 50mm tire clearance) - eyelets (or braze-ons), to put on racks and other attachments like attachments on forks, top tube, etc. - good brakes (I prefer cable disc brakes) Good luck!

As others note, the checkpoint is far better rigged for touring even though it‚Äôs a very similar frame geometry. Both are great bikes and the Domane is wonderful for chewing up big miles in a day. For extended touring with more gear the steel 520 is trek‚Äôs classic bomb-proof hauler.

data.text: From the pictures cannot see any eyelets for racks and panniers. So I would say neither. You want a bike that can carry gear and have option for fenders. Get the widest tires you can, up to 50 mm for comfort and safety. If you have big feet like me, an often overlooked metric is the clearance between your heel and the rear panniers. If you use cleats, this can become critical. Touring is not racing, go slow and enjoy the journey.
